questions.question: Which keyword is used for **else-if** (multiple conditions) in Ruby?
questions.explanation: Ruby uses elsif (one word, no 'e' after 'els'). elseif and elif are used in other languages.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
x = 0
if x
  puts "yes"
else
  puts "no"
end
```
questions.explanation: In Ruby, 0 is truthy. Only false and nil are falsy. So the if branch runs and prints "yes".

questions.question: What does **unless** mean?

options.A: Execute block when condition is false
options.B: Execute block when condition is true

questions.explanation: unless condition runs the block when the condition is false. It is equivalent to if !condition (or if not condition).

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
result = if 1 > 2 then "a" else "b" end
puts result
```
questions.explanation: if/end is an expression; it returns the value of the branch that runs. 1 > 2 is false, so "b" is returned and assigned to result.

questions.question: What is the **ternary** operator syntax in Ruby?

options.C: if condition then value else other

questions.explanation: condition ? then_value : else_value. If condition is truthy, then_value is returned; otherwise else_value.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts 5 > 3 ? "big" : "small"
```
questions.explanation: 5 > 3 is true, so the ternary returns "big".

questions.question: Which values are **falsy** in Ruby (cause if to take the else branch)?
questions.explanation: Only false and nil are falsy. 0, "", and [] are all truthy in Ruby.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
case 2
when 1 then puts "one"
when 2 then puts "two"
when 3 then puts "three"
end
```
questions.explanation: case uses === for matching. 2 === 2 is true for Integer, so the when 2 branch runs and prints "two".

questions.question: How does **case** match the value against each **when**?
questions.explanation: case uses === to compare the case value with each when. So Range#===, Class#===, regex#===, etc. are used.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
score = 85
case score
when 0..59 then puts "F"
when 60..79 then puts "C"
when 80..100 then puts "A"
else puts "?"; end
```
questions.explanation: Range#=== checks membership. 85 is in 80..100, so the third when matches and "A" is printed.

questions.question:
What is the **modifier** form of if?

(One-line: execute expression when condition is true)
questions.explanation: Ruby allows "expression if condition" at the end of a line. The expression runs only when the condition is true.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
x = 10
puts "big" if x > 5
puts "small" unless x > 5
```
questions.explanation: x > 5 is true, so "big" is printed. unless x > 5 is false (we don't run when condition is true), so "small" is not printed. Only "big".

questions.question: Can you use **else** with **unless**?
questions.explanation: unless can have an else branch. The else block runs when the unless condition is true (i.e. when we don't take the main unless block).

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
case "hello"
when String then puts "S"
when /hel/ then puts "R"
end
```
questions.explanation: case matches the first when that === the value. String === "hello" is true (kind_of?), so "S" is printed and the case ends.

questions.question:
What does **when** with multiple values do?

```ruby
case x
when 1, 2, 3 then puts "low"
when 4, 5, 6 then puts "high"
end
```

options.A: Matches if x equals any of 1, 2, or 3

questions.explanation: when 1, 2, 3 is like multiple when clauses; it matches if x === 1 or x === 2 or x === 3.

questions.question:
What is the return value of an **if** that does not run any branch?

```ruby
x = if false then 1 end
```
questions.explanation: if is an expression. If no branch runs (or the branch has no value), the if returns nil.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
if nil
  puts "a"
elsif false
  puts "b"
else
  puts "c"
end
```
questions.explanation: nil is falsy, so we skip the first branch. false is falsy, so we skip elsif. We hit else and print "c".

questions.question: Which are valid **conditional** constructs in Ruby?
questions.explanation: Ruby has if, unless, and case. There is no switch keyword; case fills that role.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
val = nil
out = val || "default"
puts out
```
questions.explanation: || returns the first truthy value. nil is falsy, so "default" is returned. Common pattern for default values.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
x = 3
unless x == 3
  puts "no"
else
  puts "yes"
end
```
questions.explanation: unless x == 3: we run the unless block only when x == 3 is false. Here x == 3 is true, so we skip the unless block and run else, printing "yes".

questions.question: What is the value of `if true; 1; end`?
questions.explanation: if is an expression. The last value in the chosen branch is the result. Here the branch returns 1.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
case
when 1 == 1 then puts "ok"
when 2 == 2 then puts "also"
end
```
questions.explanation: case without a value evaluates each when condition in order. The first true when runs (1 == 1), so "ok" is printed and case exits.

questions.question: In Ruby, is **then** required after **if** condition?

options.A: No; newline or semicolon is enough

questions.explanation: then is optional. You can use "if cond then body" on one line, or "if cond\n  body\nend" with newline.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts "" ? "truthy" : "falsy"
```
questions.explanation: Empty string "" is truthy in Ruby. Only false and nil are falsy. So the ternary returns "truthy".

questions.question: What does **case** return when no **when** matches and there is no **else**?
questions.explanation: case is an expression. If no when matches and there is no else, the case returns nil.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
x = 0
if x then puts "zero" else puts "other" end
```
questions.explanation: 0 is truthy in Ruby. So the if branch runs and "zero" is printed.

questions.question: Which expressions are **truthy** in Ruby?
questions.explanation: 0, "", and [] are all truthy. Only false and nil are falsy.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
case 3
when 1..5 then puts "in range"
when Integer then puts "integer"
end
```
questions.explanation: First when: (1..5) === 3 is true (range membership). So "in range" is printed. The second when is not evaluated.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
result = case 2
when 1 then "one"
when 2 then "two"
end
puts result
```
questions.explanation: case is an expression. The matching when returns "two", which is assigned to result and printed.

questions.question: Which is the correct way to write a **one-line if** (modifier) that runs one statement?
questions.explanation: Modifier form: statement if condition. So "puts \"hi\" if true" runs puts when the condition is true.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
case "ruby"
when /^r/ then puts "R"
when /y$/ then puts "Y"
end
```
questions.explanation: case matches the first when. /^r/ === "ruby" is true (regex match), so "R" is printed and case stops.

questions.question: What is the value of `if false; 1; else; 2; end`?
questions.explanation: if is an expression. The condition is false, so the else branch runs and returns 2.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
x = nil
if x.nil?
  puts "nil"
elsif x == false
  puts "false"
else
  puts "other"
end
```
questions.explanation: x is nil, so x.nil? is true. The first branch runs and "nil" is printed.

questions.question: Can you use **elsif** with **unless**?
questions.explanation: unless does not have elsif. Use "unless ... elsif" is invalid. For multiple conditions with unless, use if !cond1; ... elsif cond2; ... end or nested unless.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
result = if true
  1
  2
end
puts result
```
questions.explanation: The if block's value is the last expression in the branch. So 2 is returned (1 is evaluated but 2 is the result).

questions.question: What is `[] ? 1 : 2`?
questions.explanation: Empty array [] is truthy in Ruby. So the ternary returns 1.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
x = 10
y = 20
puts "big" if x > 5 && y > 10
```
questions.explanation: x > 5 is true and y > 10 is true, so the condition is true. "big" is printed.

questions.question: What does **else** in a **case** do?

options.A: Runs when no when clause matches

questions.explanation: else in case is like default: it runs when no when matches. It is optional and typically last.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
val = false
out = val ? "a" : "b"
puts out
```
questions.explanation: false is falsy, so the ternary takes the else branch and returns "b".

questions.question: What is the value of `unless true; 1; else; 2; end`?
questions.explanation: unless true means the main block is skipped (we run when condition is false). So the else branch runs and returns 2.

questions.question: Which are **falsy** in Ruby?
questions.explanation: Only false and nil are falsy. 0 and "" are truthy.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
case
when false then puts "A"
when nil then puts "B"
else puts "C"
end
```
questions.explanation: case without value: each when is a condition. When false and when nil are both falsy, so neither branch runs. The else runs and prints "C".

questions.question: In **case value**, which **when** is chosen if several match?
questions.explanation: case evaluates whens in order and runs only the first one that === the value. No fall-through like C switch.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
x = 5
if x == 5 then puts "five" end
```
questions.explanation: then is optional; it separates condition from body. x == 5 is true, so "five" is printed.

questions.question: What is the value of `if 0; 1; end`?
questions.explanation: 0 is truthy, so the if branch runs. The last (and only) expression is 1, so the if returns 1.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
amount = 120
size = case amount
  when 1..120; "S"
  when 120..170; "M"
  when 170..200; "L"
  else "XL"
end
p size
```
questions.explanation: case uses ===. 1..120 === 120 is true (120 is in the range). The first matching when wins, so "S".
